alert.note: Alert for Kootenai; Shoshone (Idaho) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Spokane (Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho)
info.headline: Flood Watch issued February 28 at 1:59PM MST until March 04 at 12:54AM MST by NWS Spokane
info.description: ...The Flood Watch continues for the following rivers in Idaho... Coeur d Alene River at Cataldo affecting Kootenai and Shoshone Counties. St Joe River at St Maries affecting Benewah County. .A warm, windy, and moist storm system will impact the region over the next 24-36 hours. Heavy rain will continue to fall into Tuesday. Temperatures will warm above freezing and remain mild into Wednesday increasing snowmelt. The combination of heavy rain and snowmelt will result in excess runoff and potential for rivers to rise quickly, some which could reach minor flood stage this week. For the Coeur d`Alene River...including Cataldo...flooding is possible. For the St Joe River at St Maries...flooding is possible. ...FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON TO LATE THURSDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding is possible. * WHERE...Coeur d Alene River at Cataldo. * WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon to late Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...At 44.0 feet, Homes near the river may experience some flooding of basements. Water will begin to cover CCC Road near the Mennonite Church. Some water will be over the section of Latour Creek Road immediately south of Interstate 90, near the campground. Due to the high water table some homes behind the Cataldo levee will be surrounded by water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 PM PST Monday the stage was 33.6 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached Wednesday morning. - Flood stage is 43.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: If you are in the watch area, remain alert to possible flooding. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor rising water levels and be prepared for possible flood warnings. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 100 AM PST.
